Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Error Quantification and Control for Gravitational Waveform Simulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to develop practical rigorous methods for estimating the error in computed waveforms from gravitational wave simulation with reliable accuracy, in support of the NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational Observatory (LIGO). The project brings together a team of applied and computational mathematicians with expertise in constructing error estimates for solutions of partial differential equations and physicists with expertise in numerical solutions of the Einstein equation and gravitational wave data analysis. The primary technical goal is to develop and analyze new mathematical and computational methods that can be used by the gravitational physics community to compute rigorous and reliably accurate estimates for the errors of numerical solutions of the Einstein equations and the gravitational waveforms that are determined from them. In particular, this research explores the following issues:
(1) Error quantification and a posteriori analysis using adjoint sensitivity techniques, and their associated numerical implementation;
(2) Adaptive algorithms that are driven by goal-oriented error control, and their associated theoretical convergence analysis; and
(3) The role of covariance symmetry and associated geometric structures in error analysis and the construction of numerical methods.
As part of the a posteriori analysis, the project team will develop the basic theory of adjoint operators and duality for the Einstein equations. This will provide the foundation for future investigations into sensitivity analysis, data assimilation and uncertainty quantification for using LIGO data. It should be emphasized that the main thrusts of the proposed research are discretization-neutral, and therefore have broad applicability to the breadth of numerical relativity codes in existence.

The NSF-supported Laser Interferometer Gravitational Observatory (LIGO) can be successful only if highly accurate gravitational waveform models are available for use as part of the data analysis process, both for detecting gravitational waves and also for measuring the physical properties of any detected signals. The strongest sources of gravitational waves are expected to be collisions between heavy, dense stars or black holes, which can only be modeled accurately using complex numerical simulations to calculate the anticipated gravitational waveforms. Such waveforms are needed to construct the filters that allow detection of the weak gravitational-wave signals in the noisy detector, and such waveforms are also needed to measure the physical properties of the sources of any detected signals. The waveform accuracy needed to accomplish the required data analysis tasks is quite high. However, the numerical relativity community has yet to develop the analytic and computational tools needed to evaluate rigorously the accuracy of the numerical waveform models. If the qualitative accuracy measures currently used by the numerical relativity community are too optimistic, the rigorous new methods developed by this project could make the difference between success and failure of LIGO. If the current numerical waveforms are in fact accurate enough, the methods developed by this project could improve the computational efficiency of determining waveforms with a specified accuracy level, and thus reduce the cost of producing them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The detection of gravity waves using LIGO shares characteristics of many important scientific and engineering applications. Namely, the goal is to infer information about the state of a complex physical system from experimental observations. The connection between the observable quantities and the state of the system is expressed as a mathematical model consisting of a set of partial differential equations. The state of the system is captured by the inputs into the model while the experimental data is gathered on quantities computed from the solution of the model. Thus, the inference requires solving an inverse problem for the model. Also, model solutions must be approximated through computation, which is often a difficult and expensive undertaking.

The LIGO experiments depend on detecting incredibly small effects, so that stochastic measurement error is a significant concern. At the same time, the models for gravitation are terribly complex PDEs posed on extremely large complex domains, hence obtaining accurate numerical solutions is also a challenging problem. Finally, the stochastic inverse problem for determination of parameters is also difficult to solve because of the “curse of dimensionality” where the costs scale adversely with the dimension of the input. These qualities make quantifying the uncertainties involved with the problem of the LIGO detection critical to scientific validation of any results.

In this project, we obtained a number of results that contribute to uncertainty quantification for scientific inference for complex models like those for gravitational waves. We extended a powerful method for computing accurate error estimates developed for certain kinds of relatively simple numerical methods for solving differential equations to the complex, physics-based discretization methods used by physicists solving models of gravitational waves. This extension was developed in a systematic fashion that provides the basis for further applications to new numerical methods as needed. We derived these estimates not only for computed solutions, but also for statistical quantities computed from solutions. We developed new approaches to using these accurate estimates to select discretizations that provide a required level of accuracy at a relatively low cost that take into account the positive effects of cancellation of error. We also continued development of a new formulation of stochastic inverse problems for parameter determination that has a rigorous mathematical foundation along with sophisticated numerical solution methods. This presents a ground-breaking advance in scientific inference. We applied this approach to solving realistic problems involved with prediction of coastal flooding during hurricanes and prediction of pollution flow in porous media, as well as began the application to detection of gravity waves.
